qas.question: What action suggested by a state, would have affecting the outcome of the electoral votes?

answers.text: ballot initiative in Colorado, known as Amendment 36

qas.question: What unique change to the electoral voting process did Colorado suggest should happen?

answers.text: under the amendment Colorado would have assigned presidential electors proportionally to the statewide vote count, which would be a unique system

qas.question: Which two states designated their assigned votes based on their districts?

answers.text: Nebraska and Maine assign electoral votes based on vote totals within each congressional district)

qas.question: Did everyone agree that Amendment 36 was a good idea?

answers.text: Detractors claimed that this splitting would diminish Colorado's influence in the Electoral College

qas.question: What was the name of the amendment passed in Nebraska?

plausible_answers.text: the way in which the state apportions its electoral votes

qas.question: What did Amendment 36 change in Nebraska?
How was Amendment 36 described when it was on the ballot in Nebraska?
Where would Nebraska's influence be diminished under the 36th Amendment?
What percentage of the population in Nebraska didn't like the amendment?

context: A <a0_0>ballot initiative in Colorado, known as <b5_0>Amendment 36<b5_0/><a0_0/>, would have changed <b6_0>the way in which the state apportions its electoral votes<b6_0/>. Rather than assigning all 9 of the state's electors to the candidate with a plurality of popular votes, <a1_0>under the amendment Colorado would have assigned presidential electors proportionally to the statewide vote count, which <b7_0>would be a unique system<b7_0/><a1_0/> (<a2_0>Nebraska and Maine assign electoral votes based on vote totals within each congressional district)<a2_0/>. <a3_0>Detractors claimed that this splitting would diminish Colorado's influence in <b8_0>the Electoral College<b8_0/><a3_0/>, and <a4_0>the amendment ultimately failed<a4_0/>, receiving only <b9_0>34%<b9_0/> of the vote.
